bakeryApp.title: Bakery Mobile Ordering App Design
bakeryApp.desc: A design of a mobile app for ordering goods from a local bakery. The app provides the customers an easy way to access detailed information on used ingredients and nutrition charts, in order to support the customers making the most suitable choices for themselves and to alleviate concerns about allergens.

overview.problemContent: Some people have limitations on what they can eat or need more information on their food for other reasons. This information isn't always easy to find.
overview.goalContent: Design an app that makes finding suitable food options faster and more comfortable.

userResearch.heading: User research summary
userResearch.competitiveAudit: The competitive audit showed lack of ingredient and nutrition information on other ordering apps/websites.
userResearch.empathy: I created empathy maps to better understand the users' wants and needs. The user group I focused on was working adults between the ages of 20 and 60 years old. Empathy maps were then refined into personas.
userResearch.revelation: Research revealed three major user pain points.

painPoints.heading: Pain points
painPoints.inconvenienceText: - Trying to find information about allergens and nutrition values feels inconvenient.
painPoints.timeText: - Finding suitable food options takes too long.
painPoints.uncertaintyText: - Not sure what the food contains. â€œCan I eat this?

persona.heading: Persona - Manu
persona.problemStatementText: - Manu is a junior employee in an HR consulting firm who needs a faster way to find suitable food options for their coworkers because of the coworkers' allergies.

userJourney.heading: User journey map - Manu
userJourney.journey: Mapping Manu's journey revealed that a way to filter the products could
userJourney.helpUsers: help the users make more confident choices

designStart.summary: After gathering empathy and understanding for the users' pain points, I drafter paper wireframes which were then turned into digital wireframes. The screens were then connected into a low-fidelity prototype and utilized for a usability study.

paperWireframes.heading: Paper wireframes
paperWireframes.iteration: Wireframing on paper enabled quick iteration and trying out different layouts for the home page before moving on to digital wireframing.
paperWireframes.ideation: I ideatiated five different versions of the home page.
paperWireframes.refinedVersion: After assessing the best features of the differend wirefames I built a refined version of the home screen.

digitalWireframes.heading: Digital Wireframes
digitalWireframes.designs: As the initial design phase continued, I made sure to base screen designs on findings from the user research.

lofiPrototype.heading: Low-fidelity prototype
lofiPrototype.userFlow: I connected the digital wireframe screens in order to create the primary user flow, which presents the process of ordering bakery goods.

usabilityFindings.heading: Usability study findings
usabilityFindings.changes: From testing the low-fidelity prototype on five users, I could determine that the following changes were needed:
usabilityFindings.backButton: Back button was missing from the profile page.
usabilityFindings.dietaryNeeds: Users felt that reading ingredient lists is tiring and there should be quicker way to find out, if the product is suitable for their dietary needs.
usabilityFindings.orders: Users needed a clearer way to access orders.

mockups.heading: Mockups
mockups.dietaryTags: Dietary tags were added to product page. Tags will help the user quickly decide if the product is suitable for them, without reading the ingredient list. The layout was modified to fit these new elements.
mockups.addToCart: 'Add to cart' button was accompanied by an element that shows how many items have been added so that the user can add many items at once and see how many items have been already added.
mockups.profilePage: Profile page was redesigned and missing back button added. All the user information can be accessed and edited in a uniform way.
mockups.sections: Information was divided into small sections, which makes it easy to read. Orders can be found at the top of the page.

keyMockups.heading: Key mockups
keyMockups.orderingFlow: Some key screens from the ordering flow.

hifiPrototype.heading: High-fidelity prototype
hifiPrototype.final: The final high-fidelity prototype presented cleaner user flows for navigating the app and ordering bakery goods.

accessibility.heading: Accessibility
accessibility.colors: WCAG guidelines on color contrast were followed.
accessibility.icons: Used icons to help make navigation easier.

takeaways.heading: Takeaways
takeaways.impactText: The app makes users feel like they can make informed decisions on their bakery ordering choices.
takeaways.whatLearnedText: I learned to trust the iteration process more. It can feel overwhelming to start from nothing, but I am happy how far I have gotten with this app design.

nextSteps.heading: Next steps
nextSteps.usabilityStudy: Conduct another round of usability studies to validate whether the pain points users experienced have been effectively addressed.
nextSteps.research: Conduct more user research to determine any new areas of need.

danceVote.title: UX and UI design of a Voting App (Thesis)
danceVote.desc: The objective of the thesis was to design a user interface for a voting application so that the audience could take part in judging. The commissioner of this thesis was Groove Connection Oy which is a limited company that organizes social partner dance competitions. The company hoped to lighten the workload of its judges. The thesis resulted in an interactive prototype that was used in the programming of the web application.

overview.problemContent: Judging in dance competitions is tiring and time consuming. How could the workload of the judges be lightened?
overview.goalContent: The goal of the project is to design the user interface for a voting application so that the audience could participate in the judging of dance competitions.

userResearch.heading: User research summary
userResearch.empathy: Empathy maps and user personas were created in order to understand better the users' needs.
userResearch.competitiveAudit: The research made it clear that there is not much competition in voting apps aimed at dance competitions.
userResearch.revelation: It was concluded that a simple, easy-to-use and accessible app would serve the cause well.

personaAntti.heading: Persona - Antti
personaAntti.problemStatementText: - Antti is a color-blind and dyslexic student who needs more websites and applications that consider people like him because he does not want to feel like an outsider.

personaJouni.heading: Persona - Jouni
personaJouni.problemStatementText: Jouni is a organizer of the vote who needs an easy-to-use app aimed at dance eventsbecause he wants the voting to go smoothly.

userJourney.heading: User journey map - Manu
userJourney.journey: Mapping Manu's journey revealed that a way to filter the products could
userJourney.helpUsers: help the users make more confident choices

ideation.heading: Ideation
ideation.crazyEights: I used the crazy eights exercise for brainstorming different home page layouts. The goal was to fit all the elements on the page in a way that feels intuitive and to keep the 'joining the voting room' functionality as the highest priority.
ideation.refinedVersion: After the exercise I evaluated each screen. I built a refined version of the home page based on my preferred features of the screens.

wireframes.heading: Wireframes
wireframes.designs: After ideating, I created the initial digital designs for the DanceVote app. These plans focused on getting an idea of how the voting process should go for the voter and what the app would look like for the vote organizer.

keyMockups.heading: Key mockups
keyMockups.votingFlow: Some key screens from the voting flow.

hifiPrototype.heading: High-fidelity prototype
hifiPrototype.final: The final high-fidelity prototype presented cleaner user flows for navigating the app and ordering bakery goods.

usabilityStudy.changes: From testing the low-fidelity prototype on seven users, I could determine that the following changes were needed:

takeaways.heading: Takeaways
takeaways.impactText: The project resulted in an interactive prototype that models the appearance and functionality of the final application. In the prototype, the user can participate in voting, view voting results or create and manage their own voting.
takeaways.whatLearnedText: Conducting usability study made me remember once again the importance of it. The user can always notice or feel something unexpected about the design.

nextSteps.heading: Next steps
nextSteps.ui: Enchance the UI with animations and images.

farmersApp.title: Web App for Farmers
farmersApp.desc: An international customer project where a web app prototype was designed and developed. The app is a refill management solution for farmers who want to sell their products with salesboxes. With the app the farmer can see real-time stock level data of the products that have been added to the database and also delete and edit the products.
